I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
program loan, and (ii) a proposed project grant, both to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
(Lao PDR) for the Secondary Education Sector Development Program.1 
 
2.  The program loan will support key policy reform actions focused on strengthening the 
secondary education subsector (SES)2 throughout the Lao PDR, and the project grant will 
finance investments that directly link to, and support delivery of, those policy actions and ensure 
they are effectively put into operation. Complementary program and project components will 
collectively  address  key  priorities  related  to  equitable  access,  quality  and  relevance,  and 
subsector management in the SES. The program will principally be national in scope, with 
access-related project investments targeted to selected disadvantaged and underserved areas.3  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The Government of the Lao PDR ascribes a high priority to education as a prerequisite 
for  sustained  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction. 4  Government  and  international 
development  partner  (IDP)  efforts  have  focused  on  the  primary  level  (grades  1–5),  and 
significant progress has been made. Gains have also been made in the SES, with the transition 
to a 7-year system marking a key milestone.5 At the same time, key gaps in access, quality and 
relevance, and subsector management undermine the contributions made by the SES and the 
entire education system to modernization, equity and inclusive growth, poverty reduction, and 
broader socioeconomic development in the Lao PDR. 
 
4.  Access. As primary education has expanded, the SES has become a key bottleneck. 
From SY2006/07 to SY2009/10, the lower secondary education (LSE) gross enrolment ratio 
(GER) rose from 53.3% to 60.2%, with the upper secondary education (USE) GER stagnant at 
34.0%.6 Aggregate figures conceal large socioeconomic and geographic gaps.7 Particularly in 
poor, rural, and largely ethnic group areas, enrolment rates decline steadily and gender gaps 
widen at higher grades. Expanding access requires policies and investments to address an 
array of demand-side issues (e.g., financial and opportunity costs, language and other cultural 
factors, and disabilities) and supply-side factors (e.g., weak school network coverage of remote 
areas, and inadequate financial and human resources), as well as quality issues. 
 
5.  Quality. Low SES enrolment and high rates of repetition and especially dropout partly 
reflect quality gaps.8 Particularly for LSE, rapid rises in the number of primary school graduates 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The SES comprises lower and upper secondary education. 
3  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided project preparatory technical assistance. ADB. 2010. Concept Paper 
for Lao People’s Democratic Republic: Basic Education Sector Development Program II. Manila. 
4  Government strategies, indicators, and analysis of progress and challenges in the education sector are detailed in 
Sector Assessment: Education (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
5  Completed during school years (SY) 2009/10 and SY2010/11, the extension of lower secondary education (LSE) 
by the Ministry of Education (MOE) from 3 years to 4 years and the subsequent addition of upper secondary 
education (USE) grade 12 aligns the Lao PDR's system of primary education (5 years), LSE (4 years), and USE (3 
years) with the international standard of 12 years of primary and secondary schooling. 
6  The GER fell slightly in SY2009/10, despite a large rise in total enrolment, due to the extension of LSE to 4 years. 
7  For example, in SY2009/10, GERs in LSE were 44.4% for girls and 56.1% for boys in the poorest districts.  
8  The national LSE dropout rate was 13% in SY2009/10 and is much higher in many poor and ethnic areas. In seven 
of the poorest provinces only 11%–25% of children are expected to reach and complete grade 11.

2 
and limited resourcing have strained capacities to provide access to good quality education. As 
part of comprehensive SES reforms, the Ministry of Education (MOE) has developed new LSE 
and USE curricula and new LSE textbooks and teacher guides, and commenced the cohort-
based phase-in of the new SES curriculum in SY2010/11. Follow-on policy and investment 
support will be critical for these reforms to become fully operational and to realize gains from 
(and meet challenges linked to) the addition of a fourth year of LSE in SY2009/10, and the 
potential  of  new  SES  curricula  to  better  feed  in  to  subsequent  learning  and  employment. 
Priorities include bolstering (i) systems and institutions providing pre- and in-service training and 
support to SES teachers;9 (ii) mechanisms for teacher deployment to poor, rural, and largely 
ethnic group areas (particularly in subjects such as science and math); and (iii) investment in 
facilities and teaching and learning materials (including textbooks and laboratory facilities). 
 
6.  Subsector management. Interlinked with access and quality issues, gaps in subsector 
management undermine learning outcomes and the internal and external efficiency of the SES. 
Low investment poses an overarching issue for the education sector, and the SES is particularly 
underresourced,  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  the  only  IDP  providing 
comprehensive support.10 Financing gaps compound other urgent SES management challenges: 
(i) institutional capacity, including the need for further rationalization alongside decentralization; 
(ii) human resources and technical and managerial capacities; (iii) planning and budgeting, as 
well as management information systems; (iv) assessment of teachers and of student learning 
outcomes, and broader quality control; and (v) enhanced mobilization of private sector actors. 
 
7.  Sector  development  program  approach.  The  Lao  PDR’s  Education  Sector 
Development Framework (ESDF) provides (i) a plan with which to operationalize the National 
Education System Reform Strategy 2006–2015, and (ii) a unified framework for government and 
IDP efforts. Dialogue toward ADB’s next country partnership strategy for the Lao PDR has 
identified education as a core sector, and the government has called on ADB to maintain its role 
as the lead IDP supporting the SES. The program will build on, consolidate, and advance key 
SES reforms catalyzed with support under the ongoing Basic Education Sector Development 
Program  (BESDP),  which  demonstrated  the  efficacy  of  the  sector  development  program 
modality.11 In particular, the program will seamlessly dovetail with BESDP support for curriculum 
reform, assisting the MOE to complete the introduction of the new 4-year LSE curriculum by 
SY2013/14 and in all three USE grades by SY2016/17. Comprehensive program and project 
support will also build on lessons, models, and capacities built under the BESDP to advance 
progress in the SES under all three ESDF pillars: (i) assuring equitable access, (ii) improving 
quality and relevance, and (iii) strengthening sector governance and performance management. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the program will be improved educational attainment in the Lao PDR. The 
outcome will be enhanced equity, quality, and efficiency of secondary education in the Lao 
PDR.12 While the program and project components will principally be national in scope, project 
investments to expand access will be targeted to 30 selected districts (para. 19).  
                                                
9  This includes lack of a clear policy on information and communication technology (ICT) for education, in particular 
for equity-enhancing and sustainable investments in low-cost ICT to improve teaching and pedagogical support. 
10 Rising national investment in recent years has been partly offset by declining IDP investment for education. The 
share of the national budget allocated to education increased from a trough of below 12.0% in FY2005 to 15.5% in 
FY2010 but remains below the 18.0% level stated in the Education Law (revised in 2007). 
11 ADB. 2006. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Grant to 
the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for the Basic Education Sector Development Program. Manila. The program 
will also link to proposed technical assistance to support education reforms, included in ADB’s 2012 pipeline. 
12 Key targets include raising the share of female primary school graduates entering LSE (Appendix 1).

3 
 C.  Outputs 
9.  Directly aligned with the Lao PDR’s ongoing SES reform agenda and the ESDF’s three 
pillars, the program’s outputs will be (i) expanded access to secondary education, (ii) improved 
delivery of new SES curricula, and (iii) strengthened SES management. 
 
1.  Program Outputs 
 
10.  Key policy actions supported under the program are outlined in paras. 11–17, with 
details provided in the development policy letter (Appendix 3) and policy matrix (Appendix 4). 
 
a.  Expanded Access to Secondary Education 
 
11.  Stipends for disadvantaged students. The MOE has put a high priority on launching 
and expanding needs-based LSE and USE stipends.13 The program and project will support 
development and demonstration of modalities to ensure efficacy and targeting to disadvantaged 
students. The policy matrix includes sequenced policy actions for development and approval of 
beneficiary selection criteria and interim implementation guidelines (including targets for girls 
and ethnic students) for MOE-administered stipends at all post-primary levels, followed by 
resourcing and launch of an expanded SES stipend program for disadvantaged students. 
 
12.  Dormitories to enhance equitable access. The MOE recognizes dormitories as a key 
instrument for addressing constraints on access, particularly for girls and ethnic group children 
in remote villages located far from secondary schools. At the same time, despite increasing 
investments,  there  is  no  concrete  policy  for  dormitories  in  the  SES.  Complemented  by 
interventions under the project component, the program will support the MOE’s completion of a 
review of existing dormitories and their impact on equitable access in the SES, followed by 
adoption of a related policy on, and guidelines for, dormitories in the subsector. 
 
b.  Improved Delivery of New Secondary Education Subsector Curricula 
 
13.  Preservice teacher training, recruitment, deployment, and utilization planning. The 
program (and complementary project support) will help further operationalize existing policies14 
via  a  series  of  policy  actions  aimed  at  (i)  MOE  approval  of  revised  national  curricula  for 
preservice teacher training for LSE and then USE, along with minimum quality standards for all 
13 teacher training institutions (TTIs);15 (ii) conduct and evaluation by MOE of a pilot test of a 
teacher placement scheme to attract TTI graduates to teach in remote areas; and (iii) approval 
by MOE of guidelines for use by provincial education services, district education bureaus, and 
institutions concerned with developing annual teacher recruitment and utilization plans. 
 
14.  Improving in-service teacher performance. Given the importance of monitoring and 
improving  teacher  performance  to  improving  quality  and  advancing  pupil-centered  active 
learning, the program will support the MOE’s development and approval of guidelines and 
adoption of an operational manual for teacher performance monitoring and evaluation (M&E). 
 
15.  Secondary education subsector curriculum reform. As noted in paras. 5 and 7, the 
introduction of an improved curriculum and related materials for the 7-year SES is a core thrust 
                                                
13 The ESDF sets a target of extending stipends to eventually cover 20% of all LSE and USE students. 
14 These include the Teacher Education Strategy and Action Plan, and the Teacher Development and Management 
Policy Framework and Action Plan developed with BESDP support and approved in 2011. 
15 The TTIs consist of 10 teacher education institutes and 3 faculties of education.

4 
of national education reforms, as reflected in the ESDF. Building directly on reforms launched 
under the BESDP and directly supported by the program’s project component, the program will 
support the completion by the MOE of the cohort-based introduction of the new LSE curriculum, 
including nationwide textbook and teacher guide distribution and related teacher training for 
fourth year LSE in SY2013/14, followed by approval of new textbooks for all USE grades.16 
  
c.  Strengthened Secondary Education Subsector Management 
 
16.  Enhanced resourcing and planning for education. The Lao PDR Education Law, 
ESDF, and other policy documents commit to increased education sector investment. The 
ESDF targets increased and better-managed nonsalary recurrent costs and the introduction of 
block grants as key thrusts. The program will directly support these thrusts, as well as measures 
such as school network mapping, which will be essential to ensure that investments in new 
school construction align with the need to efficiently and equitably expand access. Supported by 
project interventions, a series of policy actions aim at achieving (i) the 18% share of education 
in the total budget required by the Education Law; (ii) an increased share of nonsalary recurrent 
expenditures within the MOE’s total budget; (iii) development and approval of  a policy for 
introducing block grants to cover recurrent costs at all levels within the MOE system, supported 
by a block grant management manual, and subsequent allocation and release of block grants 
for LSE schools in all 30 districts classified as poorest and educationally disadvantaged (para. 
19); and (iv) MOE completion of nationwide SES school network mapping and issuance of a 
decree on its use to guide planning for future capital investment. 
 
17.  Improved  stakeholder  mobilization  and  information  and  communication 
technology strategy. A final set of policy actions will promote broader education reforms and 
sector  performance  (particularly  in  the  SES):  (i)  approval  and  launch  of  a  communication 
strategy within the MOE system and outwards to communities and other stakeholders; (ii) 
approval of a revised decree on private education;17 and (iii) approval of policy and a detailed 
strategy for appropriate information and communication technology (ICT) to support grades 1–
12 education which are clearly dictated by education aims, equity, and sustainability. 
 
2.  Project Outputs 
 
18.  The  project  grant  supports  interventions  that  closely  align  with  and  support 
implementation of the policy program. It directly supports attainment of national targets for the 
SES: outputs 2 and 3 (paras. 22–30) are nationwide in scope, while output 1 interventions 
strategically focus on 30 target districts (para. 19) for maximum impact on access.18  
 
a.  Expanded Access to Secondary Education 
 
19.  Classroom provision to expand physical access.19 The output will provide a series of 
measures  to  expand  equitable  access  in  30  targeted  districts  that  are  classified  by  the 
government as both “poorest” and “educationally disadvantaged”; these lie in 15 mostly poorer 
provinces, and are clustered along the Lao PDR’s borders. To address physical access, the

17 This builds on BESDP support to the MOE to develop the Strategy for Promoting Private Education (approved in 
2011), which includes private schools as well as private (including nonprofit) actors’ support to public schools. 
18 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2) provides more detailed

19 The project will provide one classroom per grade, one multi-use room (e.g., for science teaching and library use),

5 
program will (i) construct one new LSE school in underserved areas within each of the 30 target 
districts, (ii) build one USE classroom block20 at each of 15 existing school sites, and (iii) provide 
furniture packages (plus teaching and learning materials under output 2). 
  
20.  Direct support for disadvantaged students. The output will support (i) a baseline 
study to identify  candidates for LSE and USE  stipend support (starting in SY2012/13 and 
SY2013/14) from among eligible poor children expected to graduate in grades 5 and 9 the prior 
year; (ii) provision of 4-year stipends for roughly 1,740 poor LSE entrants; and (iii) 3-year 
stipends for roughly 1,200 poor USE entrants. Detailed guidelines (to be agreed before fund 
release) will ensure at least 50% of recipients are girls and 80% are ethnic group students.21 
 
21.  School-level support to enhance equitable access. Complementing stipend support 
in these 30 new and 30 existing LSE schools, the output will support (i) construction and 
community management of low-cost dormitories, including sex-segregated sleeping facilities 
and sanitation facilities, and mechanisms for adult supervision; (ii) remedial support targeting 
boarders in particular;22 and (iii) school access grants, to be provided in four annual cycles 
based on proposals from (and administered by) pupil–parent associations (PPAs).23 Parallel 
interventions will support expanded USE access at the 15 schools receiving USE stipends. 
 
b.  Improved Delivery of New Secondary Education Subsector Curricula 
 
22.  Preservice  training  and  placement  of  new  secondary  education  subsector 
teachers. To strengthen training and deployment of new SES teachers nationwide, the output 
will (i) assist the MOE to develop preservice teacher training curricula (aligned with new SES 
curricula) for use by all TTIs, and to introduce a TTI quality assurance system; (ii) bolstering TTI 
capacities and instructional resources; (iii) pilot testing in five districts a new placement scheme 
to attract new science teachers to LSE schools in poor and remote areas;24 and (iv) developing 
procedures, manuals, and M&E tools for teacher recruitment and utilization planning. 
 
23.  In-service teacher training and support. To prepare in-service teachers to deliver the 
new SES curriculum, the output will support (i) annual nationwide teacher training during 2012–
2016 to support completion of the rollout of new LSE and then USE curricula;25 (ii) expansion of 
the MOE’s capacity to develop ICT-based materials (e.g., TV, radio, and DVD), particularly 
those  to  support  teachers  and  teacher  training;  (iii)  capacity  development  for  secondary 
pedagogical advisors nationwide via inclusion in training-of-trainers for the in-service training, 
and annual experience-sharing meetings; (iv) pilot testing a new initiative to equip secondary 
pedagogical advisors in five districts with laptop computers and ICT materials, along with other 
support, to strengthen the advisors’ role in providing in-school support for SES teachers; and (v) 
provision of grants to allow 30 LSE science teachers to upgrade to bachelor degree level.26 
                                                
20 USE classroom blocks will be provided later in the project, often to extend an LSE school to cover USE grades. 
Sites in the noted 15 provinces will be selected after the school network mapping under output 3. 
21 Output 3 will support LSE and USE stipend programs by mobilizing  pupil–parent associations (PPAs) and 
supporting M&E, including rigorous impact evaluation, to feed into policy dialogue on stipends. 
22 Priority will be given to boarding students (especially girls), many of whom will be ethnic students from more remote 
villages, who are likely to have weaker foundations from primary school. 
23 PPA proposals for access grants will be based on local needs. Detailed guidelines (to be agreed upon before fund 
release) will specify eligible uses, including expansion of low-cost dormitories and/or remedial support, as well as 
small income-generating activities (e.g., school gardens) with a demonstrated link to increased access and equity.  
24 This will include cash transfers to support placement and retention of 25 mostly female and ethnic TTI graduates in 
their first 2 years of teaching. M&E will assess options for sustainability and scaling up, and inform refinements. 
25 Virtually all SES teachers nationwide are expected to receive 5 days of face-to-face training at least once by project 
end (SES teachers typically teach multiple grades). Training will also include content on in-school peer training. 
26 Prioritizing female and ethnic group teachers, grants will support all costs of summer training over a 3-year period,

6 
  24.  New curriculum materials (textbooks and teacher guides). Building directly on the 
BESDP (para. 7), the output will support printing and nationwide distribution of textbooks and 
teacher guides for the final 2 years of the new LSE curriculum to all schools teaching grades 8–
9  and  TTIs,  followed  by  development,  printing,  and  nationwide  distribution  of  new  USE 
curriculum materials to all schools teaching grades 10–12.27 
  
25.  Teaching and learning equipment and materials. To support improved teaching in 
schools and classrooms provided under output 1, the program will provide packages of teaching 
and learning resources to the 30 new LSE schools and 15 USE classroom blocks.28 
 
26.  Support for improved student assessment. The output will provide technical support 
to the MOE to strengthen national examinations for LSE and USE completion (grades 9 and 
12), including drafting of related rules and regulations. In parallel, it will support development of 
the assessment of the student learning outcomes protocol for grades 9 and 12. 
 
c.  Strengthened Secondary Education Subsector Management 
 
27.  Support  for  enhanced  subsector  analysis.  The  output  will  support  (i)  further 
institutional analysis of the SES; (ii) nationwide SES school network mapping to identify unmet 
demand and guide planning for network expansion; (iii) strengthening and integration of existing 
management information system modules, in particular related to SES management; and (iv) 
focused support on needs analysis and planning for the 30 districts targeted under output 1. 
 
28.  Capacity  building  for  secondary  education  subsector  staff  at  all  levels.  The 
program will support (i) phased and multimodal capacity building for education sector staff at all 
levels;29 (ii) development and launch of the new MOE communication strategy (para. 17); (iii) 
policy dialogue to revise the existing decree on private education, and mobilization of private 
(including nonprofit) actors’ support to the SES; and (iv) the MOE’s development of the policy 
and strategy on low-cost ICT to support teaching, learning, and school management. 
 
29.  Community  engagement  in  school  support  and  management.  PPAs  will  be 
established or reconstituted in 75 schools  supported under output 1, and will be provided 
capacity building to support their management of stipends and access grants (paras. 20–21) 
and strengthen the PPAs’ broader roles in expanding local enrolment and school management. 
 
30.  Monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  output  will  support  project-wide  M&E,  including 
capturing sex-disaggregated data on LSE and USE stipends, teacher training, and measures 
such as student enrolments and grade progression. A rigorous independent impact evaluation 
will center on the effect of LSE stipends on outcomes such as enrolment and completion rates.30 
 
D.  Program Costs and Financing 
 
31.  Program financing is estimated at $42.4 million equivalent (Table 1). The government 
has requested a loan and grant from ADB’s Special Funds resources as indicated in Table 1. 
 
                                                                                                                                                       
and will include a final payment on completion and retention in the same school location.

32.  Program  loan  financing  plan.  To  support  direct  and  indirect  adjustment  costs  of 
reforms  foreseen,  the  government  has  requested  a  program  loan  in  various  currencies 
equivalent to SDR6,314,000 from ADB's Special Funds resources. The loan will have a 24-year 
term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace 
period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan agreement.31 Determination of the program loan amount took into account factors including 
(i) the scope of proposed policy actions; (ii) the relative importance the government ascribes to 
the education sector (including the SES), reflected in growing budgetary allocations; and (iii) the 
short- and medium-term costs of the proposed policy actions and the associated financing 
gap.32 The program loan will be released in two equal tranches upon fulfillment of conditions 
expected for achievement by the end of 2013 (tranche 1) and the end of 2016 (tranche 2).33 
 
33.  Project grant investment plan. The project is estimated at $32.4 million equivalent 
(Table 2). The government has requested a grant not exceeding $30.0 million from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources to help finance the project, including taxes and duties and specified 
recurrent costs.34 The government will contribute $2.4 million, principally in-kind for provision of 
land, project management unit and consultant office accommodation (including utilities), and 
staff inputs.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
35.  The economic returns to secondary education are very high in developing countries.36 At 
the national level, the role of the SES in supporting growth will be especially vital as the Lao 
PDR transitions from a planned to a market economy, from a subsistence to a commercial and 
regionally  integrated  economy,  and  from  an  agrarian  to  a  more  urbanized  society.37 For 
individuals, the socioeconomic returns that result from completing LSE and USE are particularly 
high for girls and include access to the formal sector, higher-paying jobs, lower fertility, and 
increased investment in human capital of the next generation. In terms of fiscal burden, the 
incremental costs (investment and recurrent) associated with the project have a peak value of 
2.6% of the total education budget midproject and fall below 0.5% post-project, which is deemed 
modest and sustainable. Moreover, costs may be largely offset by sizeable efficiency gains due 
to increased completion of LSE and USE (dropout currently constitutes major wastage of state

investments) as well as low-cost, efficient, and evidence-based models for future investments in 
priority areas including stipends, dormitories, schemes to attract and retain teachers in more 
remote areas, and low-cost forms of ICT to support teaching and learning. 
 
B.  Governance 
36.  Assessments of MOE financial management and procurement capacity were conducted, 
with mitigation measures identified (para. 40). The MOE has extensive experience with ADB 
projects, and project management will benefit from the continuity of roles by the Department of 
Secondary Education, the project management unit, and other units under the BESDP. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government and the MOE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are 
described in the project administration manual.38 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
37.  Poverty.  Pro-poor thrusts are mainstreamed within all three outputs under both the 
program and project. Supporting pro-poor policy thrusts under the program, project investments 
directly  or  indirectly  address  constraints  facing  the  poor  and  other  disadvantaged  groups, 
including (i) addressing direct and opportunity costs of education by providing needs-targeted 
stipends  and  school  access grants  in  the  30 highly  disadvantaged  districts;  (ii)  enhancing 
curricular relevance; (iii) increasing the supply of qualified teachers in poor rural areas; (iv) 
promoting participation by all students via training on student-centered learning and (in target 
schools)  remedial  support  for  disadvantaged  children  (e.g.,  poor  children  from  non-Lao-
speaking families); (v) providing textbooks and library materials; and (vi) expanding LSE school 
networks to unserved areas in 30 districts, and providing LSE and USE dormitories, particularly 
for girls and other poor ethnic group students from remote villages.39 
 
38.  Gender. The program also tackles gender issues under all three outputs. To address 
access constraints that often disproportionately affect girls, the gender action plan ensures that 
(i) new LSE schools are located in areas with low female enrolment; (ii) civil works at all LSE 
and USE sites include sex-segregated toilets; and (iii) poor girls receive 50% of dormitory 
spaces, stipends, and remedial learning opportunities. Quality-related actions include ensuring 
gender sensitivity in new curriculum materials (and via teacher training), and that females 
receive 50% of places in (i) all preservice and in-service teacher training for LSE and USE 
teachers, (ii) the pilot teacher placement scheme, and (iii) teacher qualification upgrade grants. 
Output  3  will  (i)  prioritize  female  representation  in  all  management  training  programs  and 
support strategies; (ii) conduct advocacy campaigns on the benefits of girls’ schooling and 
promote their education in science; and (iii) provide recognition awards for districts with good 
equity-enhancement practices and increased access for girls, especially ethnic girls. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
39.  In accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program is classified 
category C for involuntary resettlement and environment, having no significant adverse impacts. 
It is classified category B for indigenous peoples (termed “ethnic groups” in the Lao PDR). All 
three program outputs emphasize access, quality, and SES management in poor, remote, and

procurement capacity assessment reflected in Appendix 18 to the project administration manual. 
39 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy, Gender Action Plan, and Indigenous Peoples Plan (Ethnic Group 
Plan) (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
ethnic group areas.40 Key features of the ethnic group plan include ensuring that (i) ethnic 
groups receive (a) 80% of dormitory spaces, stipends, and remedial learning opportunities, (b) 
80% of places for a pilot teacher placement scheme and for teacher qualification upgrade grants, 
and (c) preferential access to in-service training (including as trainers); (ii) all textbooks and 
other materials developed under the project are ethnicity-sensitive; and (iii) institutional analysis, 
school network mapping, M&E, and other analysis include ethnic group issues and criteria. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
40.  Potential risks include a faltering MOE commitment to sector strategies and targets, and 
lost momentum on budgetary increases. These will be mitigated by the program’s reinforcement 
of the government’s existing reform agenda, ESDF, and Education Law, including through the 
two-tranche program loan. Operational-side risks (e.g., related to financial management) will be 
minimized through continuity in project management structures with the BESDP, development 
of clear guidelines for key interventions, and consultant support. Major risks and mitigating 
measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.41 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
41.  The  government  and  MOE  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  sector 
development program shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement as described in detail in the project administration manual and loan and grant 
documents. The government and MOE have also agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
sector development program, which are set forth in the related agreements. Additionally, under 
the grant, no disbursement shall be made for stipends or access grants (paras. 20–21) prior to 
MOE approval of detailed guidelines for these programs. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
42.  I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  and  grant  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR6,314,000 to the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic for the Secondary Education Sector Development Program 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% 
per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 
24  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8 years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
agreement presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $30,000,000 to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 
from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources,  for  the  Secondary  Education  Sector 
Development  Project,  on  terms  and  conditions  that  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the 
Board.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BESDP  –  Basic Education Sector Development Program 
  ESDF  –  Education Sector Development Framework 
  GER  –  gross enrolment ratio 
  ICT  –  information and communication technology 
  IDP  –  international development partner 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
  LSE  –  lower secondary education 
  M&E  –  monitoring and evaluation 
  MOE  –  Ministry of Education  
  PPA  –  pupil–parent association 
  SES  –  secondary education subsector 
  TTI  –  teacher training institution 
  USE  –  upper secondary education 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
and its agencies ends on 30 September. FY before a calendar year denotes the 
year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2011 ends on September 2011. 
(ii)  The  school  year  (SY)  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  starts  in 
September and ends in June of the following year, e.g., SY2010/11 starts in 
September 2010 and ends in June 2011.  
(iii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
